description: From earlier glimse, from Middle English glimsen (“to glisten, be dazzling, glance with the eyes”), akin to Middle High German glimsen (“to glow, smoulder”), Middle High German glinsen (“to shine, glimmer”), Middle Dutch glinsen and Middle Low German glinsen, glintzen, glinzen (“to shine, shimmer”), Dutch glinsteren (“to glitter, sparkle, shimmer, glint, glance”).

entries.meaning: A brief look, glance, or peek.
examples: I only got a glimpse of the car, so I can tell you the colour but not the registration number.

verbs.description: glimpse (third-person singular simple present glimpses, present participle glimpsing, simple past and past participle glimpsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To see or view briefly or incompletely.
examples: Synonyms: perceive, notice, detect, espy, spot, catch sight of
I have only begun to glimpse the magnitude of the problem.
